text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with puff pastry shells that's
right you can also call these Volleyball
if you're French which you're not but
regardless of what you call them these
beautiful pastry cups are so versatile
and definitely a technique any serious
cook needs to know so let's go ahead and
get started and for this you're going to
need some frozen puff pastry which is
very easy to find these days in the
frozen section in the supermarket and it
usually comes folded in like three or
four panels so what we want to do is
just let that stuff thaw enough so we
can separate it and I'm going to do that
right on a Silpat lined baking sheet and
before we start cutting we're going to
go ahead and brush these with an egg
wash and one of the secrets of this
technique is a double layer of puff
pastry so this egg wash is going to help
seal those two pieces of dough together
so we'll brush that over and pretty much
the whole key to these puff pastry
shells is to work with this stuff as
close to frozen as possible and that's
going to allow for the maximum height on
these and also we want them to bake up
kind of straight they don't have to be
perfect as mine certainly weren't but
bottom line we want to work with this
dough as cold as possible and then we'll
go ahead and grab a round pastry cutter
obviously the size is up to you this
techniques can work whether you're
making big shells or small shells what
I'm going to do is cut out two circles
and obviously remove the excess dough
unlike a biscuit dough or a pie dough
you can't really re-roll puff pastry and
have it work the same but don't discard
it put it back in the freezer there's
things we can do with that I'll touch on
that on the blog but anyway we're going
to cut our two pieces of dough and then
we're going to take a slightly smaller
cutter and punch out the center of one
of the pieces just right in the center
like that and then we'll lay that over
the top of the other piece and we'll
carefully try to pull that cutter away
with a minimum amount of damage is we
don't want to match the edges of this
puff pastry together alright so use a
very light touch try not to press and
squeeze this dough together too much and
all these directions are going to make a
lot more sense once this bakes if you
are too rough with this stuff and smoosh
all the edges together it just won't
raise this high and straight as if you
didn't okay so be careful so that's
basically the method I like doing the
pieces separately there is one
alternative method you can use where you
cut the first piece of pastry but you
don't remove it from the cutter you just
press another piece and then take the
smaller cutter and cut out the center
and of course we're going to make sure
we go down at least through the first
layer with that Center cut and as you'll
notice that one's next to the Silpat
logo so we'll keep an eye on the one in
that position because as you
that one ended up cooking a little
differently because we used a different
technique so kind of interesting or not
but anyway that is another way you can
do it and then these are pretty much
ready for the oven
although I do like to give them a little
more egg wash before they go in alright
we want these to have that signature
shiny beautiful golden brown finish so
let's give them a little extra egg wash
and once that set we'll go ahead and
transfer those into the center of a very
well preheated 400 degree oven for about
20 to 25 minutes that of course will
depend on the size but about 20 minutes
or so until they look like this they
should have risen magnificently and like
I said have a beautiful brown finish and
because my puff pastry was a little more
thought than I wanted to these did not
bake up perfectly straight and that's
simply because the edges of those two
pieces of puff pastry got smeared
together when we cut it and that
prevented part of it from rising as high
as the other
although when these things are filled
nobody will care as you've heard me say
before it's the imperfections that make
this kind of thing look perfect so I
don't know about you but I was very
happy with these and at that point you
might think you're done but you're not
these are not ready to use yet you want
to let these cool in the warm oven so
what I like to do is just open the door
put them back in leave the door open we
don't want these to continue cooking we
just want them to cool slowly in that
warm oven and that's going to help them
dry out a little more and just be a
little crisper and a little nicer so I
let mine cool in there for about an hour
or so at which point they are officially
ready to use of course we're going to
need to remove the top dough so we can
fill them and what works best for this
is a small serrated knife which almost
nobody has so what works very well would
be a steak knife those are usually kind
of thin and pointy and have a little bit
of Sur aide to the blade so we'll just
go around carefully cut out that Center
and that puff pastry shell is ready to
fill so a very very simple technique if
you know the trick and of course what
you fill these with is up to you you
either Kubla Khan of your Vallejo many
of you saw me use these for lobster
Newburg recently but there's just so
many other fillings you could use from
other savory things like beef stew you
can make your chicken and biscuits and
use this instead of biscuits then
obviously there's countless dessert
options fresh fruit whipped cream maybe
a vanilla custard with chocolate ganache
oh man that would be good but anyway I
really do hope you give those a try
head over to food wishes calm for all
the ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always
enjoy
